text: In order to get hypergrowth, you have to have organic, inbound, and viral word of mouth. You can't pay enough to grow at those rates and have a viable company.
speaker: Carilu Dietrich
context: Lenny asks Carilu about the key components that contribute to hypergrowth in companies. Carilu explains that achieving hypergrowth relies on organic growth methods such as word of mouth, rather than relying on paid marketing strategies. She emphasizes that a product that users love is essential for sustaining such growth.
text_ko: 하이퍼그로스(hypergrowth)를 이루려면 유기적인(organic), 인바운드(inbound), 그리고 바이럴(viral) 입소문이 필요해요. 그런 속도로 성장하려면 돈으로 해결할 수 없고, 지속 가능한 회사가 될 수 없어요.
text_zh: 要实现超高速增长，必须依靠有机增长、内生增长和病毒式口碑传播。单靠支付费用无法达到这样的增长率，也无法维持一个可持续的公司。
text_es: Para lograr un hipercrecimiento, es necesario contar con un boca a boca orgánico, entrante y viral. No puedes pagar lo suficiente para crecer a esos ritmos y tener una empresa viable.
key_sentence: Hypergrowth requires organic, inbound, and viral word of mouth for viability.

text: Hypergrowth companies go through the stages of growth that would take other companies five years or 10 years, right? They're going from 10 to 50, they're going from 50 to 100, they're going from 100 to 200.
speaker: Carilu Dietrich
context: Lenny and Carilu discuss the characteristics of hypergrowth companies. Carilu describes how these companies experience rapid growth in a compressed time frame, achieving milestones that would typically take much longer for traditional companies. This rapid scaling requires hiring leaders who are experienced in navigating the next stages of growth.
text_ko: 하이퍼그로스(hypergrowth) 기업들은 다른 기업들이 5년이나 10년 걸릴 성장 단계를 짧은 시간 안에 지나가요. 10에서 50으로, 50에서 100으로, 그리고 100에서 200으로 성장하는 거죠.
text_zh: 超高速增长的公司经历的成长阶段，其他公司可能需要五年或十年才能完成，对吧？它们从10增长到50，从50增长到100，从100增长到200。
text_es: Las empresas en hipercrecimiento atraviesan etapas de crecimiento que a otras empresas les llevarían cinco o diez años, ¿verdad? Están pasando de 10 a 50, de 50 a 100, de 100 a 200.
key_sentence: Hypergrowth companies experience compressed time frames for growth stages.

text: If you're unemployed, it's tough. It's a tough time. There's a lot of supply. And so I think you just really need endurance and grit.
speaker: Carilu Dietrich
context: Lenny asks Carilu for advice for individuals trying to find a job in a challenging market. Carilu acknowledges the difficulties of being unemployed and stresses the importance of resilience and perseverance, or 'grit,' during tough economic times. She emphasizes that maintaining endurance is crucial for eventual success.
text_ko: 실직 상태면 힘든 시기예요. 공급이 많아서 더 어려운 것 같아요. 그래서 정말 인내심과 끈기가 필요하다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 如果你失业了，这段时间确实很困难。市场上竞争激烈，供给过剩。因此，我认为你需要具备耐力和韧性。
text_es: Si estás desempleado, es difícil. Es un momento complicado. Hay mucha oferta. Por eso creo que realmente necesitas resistencia y determinación.
key_sentence: Endurance and grit are essential in a challenging market for the unemployed.

text: Picking your industry will propel your career, and picking the right company will propel your career, and then doing a good job will propel your career.
speaker: Carilu Dietrich
context: Lenny and Carilu discuss strategies for accelerating career growth. Carilu explains that choosing the right industry and company can significantly influence one’s career trajectory. She emphasizes that consistent performance and quality work are equally important for advancing one's professional journey.
text_ko: 산업을 잘 선택하면 경력이 쭉 뻗어나가고, 그 다음에 좋은 회사를 선택하면 더 잘 나가고, 마지막으로 일을 잘 하면 경력이 더 발전해요.
text_zh: 选择行业能推动你的职业发展，选择合适的公司也能推动你的职业发展，而做好本职工作更能推动你的职业发展。
text_es: Elegir tu industria impulsará tu carrera, seleccionar la empresa adecuada también la impulsará, y hacer un buen trabajo la llevará aún más lejos.
key_sentence: Choosing the right industry and company will propel your career trajectory.

text: There's no shortcuts to knowing a lot. One of the people I admire most is Tomasz Tunguz... he was like, 'I'd just wake up 5:00 or 6:00 AM every morning and write three to four blogs a week for 10 years.'
speaker: Carilu Dietrich
context: Lenny asks Carilu about the value of hard work in achieving success. Carilu shares her admiration for Tomasz Tunguz, who dedicated significant time and effort to writing consistently over many years. She underscores that there are no shortcuts to acquiring knowledge, and that discipline is essential for success.
text_ko: 많은 것을 아는 데는 지름길이 없어요. 제가 가장 존경하는 사람 중 한 명인 Tomasz Tunguz가 이렇게 말했어요. '나는 매일 아침 5시나 6시에 일어나서 10년 동안 매주 블로그를 3개에서 4개씩 썼어.'
text_zh: 没有捷径可以获得丰富的知识。我最钦佩的人之一是Tomasz Tunguz，他曾说过：“我每天早上5点或6点起床，每周写三到四篇博客，持续了十年。”
text_es: No hay atajos para adquirir conocimiento. Una de las personas que más admiro es Tomasz Tunguz... él decía: 'Me despertaba a las 5:00 o 6:00 AM cada mañana y escribía de tres a cuatro blogs a la semana durante 10 años.'
key_sentence: There are no shortcuts; discipline is key to gaining knowledge over time.

text: The CMO isn't focused enough on the revenue. So some CMOs get focused more on the pipeline or the awareness, and the CEO doesn't feel like they really have a partner in driving the revenue.
speaker: Carilu Dietrich
context: Carilu discusses the challenges faced by Chief Marketing Officers (CMOs) in building trust with CEOs. She points out that many CMOs fail to prioritize revenue generation, which can lead to a lack of partnership with the CEO. This disconnect often results in CMOs being perceived as less effective.
text_ko: CMO가 수익에 충분히 집중하지 않는 경우가 있어요. 그래서 어떤 CMO들은 파이프라인(pipeline)이나 인지도(awareness)에 더 신경 쓰고, 그러다 보니 CEO는 수익을 올리는 데 진정한 파트너가 없다고 느끼는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 首席营销官（CMO）对收入的关注不够。有些首席营销官更关注销售渠道（pipeline）或品牌认知（awareness），而首席执行官（CEO）则感觉他们在推动收入方面并没有真正的合作伙伴。
text_es: El CMO no está lo suficientemente enfocado en los ingresos. Algunos CMOs se centran más en el pipeline o en la visibilidad, y el CEO siente que no tiene un verdadero socio en la generación de ingresos.
key_sentence: CMOs often disconnect from revenue generation by focusing too much on the pipeline.
